GBAeJq9AP6R8YXrDSL8Zfg.text: Had I written this review before my last visit to Tierra Brindisa it would have certainly got the full five stars, but while the food was still faultless and delicious my recent trip proved that the credit crunch is hurting a major part of the restaurant experience: the atmosphere. We went on a Saturday night, and a few months ago this restaurant would have been packed to the rafters and buzzing with chat, but there were only two tables taken and we were the only customers at the bar. The staff were all standing around looking very bored and it was all a bit too quiet, not what you're looking for in a tapas place. But aside from that I really can't fault Tierra Brindisa; everything on the menu sounds and tastes fantastic, from the gooey tortilla to the melt in the mouth steak and cheese on toast, all the way to the desserts like melted white chocolate on toast, and fruit salad with olive oil and mint. There are daily specials which are equally good and top quality, the wines and sherries are delicious and the coffee is great. If it weren't for the tumbleweed blowing through the place it would be full marks here.

viThI3VdDXlJmp8mKo9i5g.text: I have enjoyed tapas in Barcelona and Madrid but Tierra Brandisi is as good as anything I've eaten in Spain. The food is delicious and it's difficult deciding what to order because everything on the menu looks fantastic. I recommend the pan fried sea bass with vegeatbles, olive oil mash and the prawns with garlic and chilli. If it's your first time eating  tapas the staff are more than willing to explain the dishes. Not only is the food great but there is an excellent wine list although it is quite expenive and many are only available by the bottle.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom

AbRzLAtfSQ39Nmpg3bwTkg.text: Part of the growing Brindisa empire, Tierra Brindisa in Soho takes things to a new level. You can book, which you can't for other tapas bars in this small chain. Brindisa (a small Spanish importer with a sideline in tapas bars) specialises in fresh, traditional and lesser known Spanish foods and wines. The results are tremendous. We had some of the following - olives stuffed with orange and dressed with pepper and crushed clove; carpaccio of cod with red onion and orange; spinach with pine nuts and raisins; potato omellette; scallop with garlic, chilli, smoked paprika and bacon. I'm sure there was more. Oh yes, marvellously mellow Rioja. Each dish was faultless. The service was flawless. The decor was without fault. Everything was lovely. Disabled access to the restaurant is available but as I recall, the loos are downstairs so not entirely practical from that POV. From my experience though, 5 stars for food, service and decor.

vYdr8LsghhOnlwujd4fn9Q.text: If half stars were allowed, I'd add one to my review for this place. To start with, the food was quite good, but our visit started off on the wrong foot. I arrived early for once, and grabbed prime seating by the window. My other friends joined shortly and one of the guys went to the men's room to wash his hands while the rest of us perused the menu. He came back, a bit disturbed, and quickly grabbed the attention of a waitress. Apparently, one of the cooks in the kitchen had rushed out of the toilet when he entered, and proceeded to exit without washing his hands! The hostess rushed back to talk to the chefs, then returned to reassure us that he had subsequently washed his hands, but it was a bit of a disturbing start to the evening. Once food and wine were ordered, however, the experience only got better. The potato omelette, as mentioned previously, is well worth a try. The octopus and the gambas were also of note -- though the servings were a bit on the small side (there were exactly 4 prawns). Dessert was a definite highlight, consisting of a near perfect molten chocolate cake, but by that point the wine probably took over the taste buds. Overall a pretty good experience, but I'd be a bit concerned if their sanitary habits weren't improved...

0w1KZq7lQ6UHtyCH1UxprQ.text: Possibly the best tapas I've had in London. One frustration of the evening was that many items that we wanted off the menu were unavailable. But the lentil stew was sublime, the ham was like melting butter in the mouth. The wine we had was pretty fine too. Friendly staff and despite being a very busy Saturday night, there was no sense of being rushed out to turn the table. Will be coming back definitely!

HRm6YJYslV-hzzvpl-uCBg.text: This place is really realy lovely. It is part of the growing trend of the cut-above tapas restaurant. There is nothing ordinary about the food, service or drink in this place. We ordered 4 dishes between the two of us, and there was plenty of food. The Red mullet and the Port fillet (rare) must have a special mention as they were just amazing.

RtcjF1rTenyFWTy45yLH8g.text: Was in town & met a mate who works in Kingly St for lunch.Cosy little place, bustling with lunchtime peeps. We ordered, Bomba(meat croquette), cuttlefish pasta, lemon chicken, potatas bravas, tortilla & catalan bread with tomatoes.Dishes were very tasty, only issue was that the bomba was fridge cold in the middle! Good spot for lunch & reasonable at 30quid for two.

CvjWC2fgb8YRG-fOMWdAtQ.text: I was taken here for lunch today by my Spanish boss, who assured me that - whilst not entirely authentic - it is nonetheless very good.  And she's hard to please (I should know), so I'm inclined to believe her.As always with these places, the portions were disappointingly small and the prices disconcertingly high.  The lamb cutlets were tender and juicy with a sprinkling of mint leaves and some sort of garlic butter but you only get two tiny little pieces.  The octopus was yumsters.  The chorizo on toast (it sounds a lot posher in Spanish) felt like it was missing something, but everything else was excellent.  However considering it cost over £80 for four of us (one Coke each, no alcohol, no bottled water) and we had to stop off at the newsagent for an icecream to stave off the inevitable mid-afternoon hunger pangs, it kind of takes the mick.I also didn't like the fact that bathrooms look pretty from a distance but the taps are so low to the trendy trough basin that you scrape your knuckles on the stonework.  It was representative of the whole tapas experience, actually; good in theory, bad in practice.  Also bloody clever, because if you just keep ordering until you're full, the bill adds up at an alarming rate and you don't notice until you're handing over your credit card and wondering if it's too late to call the bank and cancel your account.

FpK8tqMPC6kkhRXnZsgxgw.text: Food and atmosphere pleasant but unfortunately the trend of any 'Tapas' type restaurant overcharging for fairly pedestrian (but still reasonable quality) Spanish fare continues.  That ordinarily wouldn't have been so much of an issue had the service made up for it. Interesting wine list, and dessert options which could have easily been explored further had we been able to attract the attention of either of the two waitresses standing not five feet away. I did manage to make eye contact several times but as a paying customer I didn't seem to rate much of a mention in comparison to a detailed discussion regarding the relative merits of various rental properties in London's Soho.  We went very early on a Saturday night and the restaurant was only about a 3rd full - maybe the staff work best under pressure and hence the other reviews? To add final insult, a 12.5% 'discretionary' tip was automatically added to the bill, which we literally had to stand up and make as if to walk out to receive.  To his credit, the manager asked what went wrong and then apologized profusely for the shortcomings - but only after our discretion was employed re the tip. Unfortunately this all occurred in front of one of the staff members - resulting in a rather frosty farewell. I'd recommend considering using your discretion and steering clear.

85Ur7EdeHAbxHHk1BVDgHg.text: This tapas place is conveniently situated just off carnaby street and is actually bit bigger on the inside than it looks. When you get through the door the whole room is bright and airy, felt more like a cafe but without the feeling of being over crowded as the tables were nicely spaced out so that you wouldn't be getting elbowed as your trying to eat. The grilled sea bass was tasty and the ham and cheese croquetta was delish! The staff were friendly and attentative, they were very obliging when we found our garlic bread to be to oily and changed it for us. This place seemed very popular during lunch time so can't imagine what it'l  be like for dinner, prob more packed! Will be making another booking sometime soon me thinks!

8VDdJPVEMVxdPv2lkjgBrA.text: All tapas we had were excellent! The service was great and the price very reasonable. I particularly recommend the Gordal Olives, the Ox Cheeks and the Pulpo a la Gallega.

nglnq5KYHYUFCGLVfy3rWw.text: Very good food and service.  It also seems to be a little less well known/appreciated as it was fairly easy to find a table for lunch.My only gripes are:-- overpriced (but hey its right off Soho square in London)-- seating is not that comfortable (esp. for larger groups)

Bc3CWUUdjAsFavr3BSoCDw.text: Absolutely fabulous tapas! its a quaint little tapas bar with excellent service. The highlight of the place though was the food. The potato omelette was unlike anything we've ever had before it makes the standard stuff at other Spanish places seem like cardboard! The chorizo in cider was really delicious, the meat just melting in your mouth. But the highlight was the honey glazed fillet wrapped in aubergine. The meat was so tender and juicy, and the mango chutney that came with it was tantalizingly spicy. The only thing that disappointed was the toast with olive oil, which was rather burnt. We were surprised they got that wrong as its such a simple thing compared to the culinary delicacies we'd just eaten! Bill came up to around £45 for 2 with non-alcoholic drinks, a tad bit pricey but you do get good tapas!

k9BXIFMgKKTwNTsCBlletw.text: We went for a very long and lazy afternoon lunch. I'm partial to tapas so the restaurant started with a couple of starts before I even entered. The space is light and airy. The back area has loads of skylights and an open kitchen so you know you're getting good clean food. We had a group of 8 people for lunch which was the perfect number. We were able to try all sorts of dishes... just small tastes. Although, I could have eaten my very own portion of the honey glazed goats cheese and the warm spinach salad. But I suppose that would defeat the idea of tapas. We started with breads, dipping oils, cold meats, cheeses, peppers and corn nuts, then moved on to Spanish omelets, chicken croquettes, prawns, scallops, salads and more cheese. We finished with an assortment of desserts; the flan, the moist chocolate cake and the plum compote were to die for. I'm a very picky dessert person so it's quite impressive for me to find three desserts that I really like, all in one place! All of this was accompanied by a lot of drink. We started with champagne, moved on to white and finished with a fantastic dessert wine. The pairings were perfect for the meal. I'm dying to go back already we only left the restaurant a mere 20 hours ago.

t38rUizWs1Lj_LcJuBpUBg.text: Small, casual style restaurant with authentic, delicious tapas at a great price.  The scallops and lamb are particularly delicious! Service was friendly, efficient and discreet and I'd definitely recommend it!

I40HOLszeWR7qqotKiivsw.text: I had a blind date meeting the lovely Skinny Bib for the first time at Tapas Brindisa. (Look at the Skinny Bib's excellent write up here, I almost have nothing to add!) Unfortunately the food was not as pleasant as the company. Tapas Brindisa in Soho has just opened a couple of weeks ago (there was 'Tierra Brindisa' before) and we went in the soft opening period with 20% off the food. Its older brother on the corner of Borough Market has been around what seems like forever and is always completely packed. I ate there once and was not as blown away by the food as many others. Mind you, Spanish is not my favourite cuisine and so I might need a little bit more then just 'good' to convince me. Convinced I was not by new Tapas Brindisa. But let's start with the some positive notes. I did love the space of the Soho joint which is bright with rustic wood furniture and direct view of the kitchen. We went on a sunny day and the room was bathed in beautiful light. But now the food. For me the highlight of the meal was the the Pan de Coca (3.50), basically pan con tomate which I couldn't get enough of on my holiday in Catalonia. Toasted country bread is rubbed with garlic and ripe tomato and drizzled with olive oil. Yum! But in the end it's just bread and doesn't require a huge amount of cooking skill. I rather liked the Padron Peppers (3.50). Apart from the amazing colour, they were nicely seasoned and non-greasy. An excellent bar snack. I am glad my dinner companion insisted on the Iberico de Bellota Ham (22) which was lean and beautifully flavoured. Not cheap though! I am not a ham expert at all so I can't judge if it REALLY was worth 22 pounds. I kind of doubt it though. The meal went downwards with the cooked dishes. We only tried a couple of them as the waitress pointed out that they recommend only 4-5 dishes per two people. I liked this actually as one tends to over-order in small plate restaurants but on the other hand we ended up with a maybe slightly imbalanced selection of dishes. The Traditional Potato Tortilla (4.50) was tremendously bland and of soggy consistency. We didn't like it at all. Even worse the Escalivada (5.50) which was one of the least attractive dishes I have seen in a long time. I easily forgive bad presentation if the food is good which was not the case here. The aubergines and red peppers were tasteless and drowned in olive oil. Don't get me wrong, I love olive oil, but enough is enough! Pan de Coca (3.50)Padron Peppers (3.50)Iberico de Bellota Ham (22)Traditional Potato Tortilla (4.50)Escalivada (5.50) One problem we had when ordering was that the menu is really confusing and difficult to navigate. There are 'Tapas, Brindisa Classics and Parrilla Soho as subheading. The dishes in each category all seemed to be tapas? As I say confusing. I do prefer the way it's done for example at the Opera Tavern where you have Meat, Fish and Vegetarian Tapas subheadings which enables you to order a balanced selection of dishes without having to study the menu for hours. I am sure Tapas Brindisa is going to do well in the current small plate hype but I think you can do much better than that. I got a strong recommendation for Barrafina (which I never managed to go to because I don't like queuing) and the new tapas place (Jose Tapas) in Bermondsey Street. Maybe these will finally convince me of the brilliance of the Spanish cuisine. I shall keep you posted. here some pictureshungryinlondon.com/2011/…

VgXpj1CXs7txOfRDJC4uCw.text: Full disclosure: I dragged my friends here for it's ties to BBC Sherlock (Don't look at me like that, they didn't have any better suggestions) We really enjoyed our meal. It's been a while, but I remember loving and wanting more of almost everything we ordered. The drinks were absolutely to die for as well. After seeing my love of all things goats cheese, the waiter suggested an off-menu item that they were trying out. (Lightly fried squashblossom stuffed with goat's cheese and drizzled with honey)  and I have been craving it ever since.

LWKMm11Z15zq_sZcYM03Hg.text: This is the real deal. Me gusta mucho. Muchobigtime.If you know the Tapas Brindisa spot at Borough Market, as you surely will, you'll have high expectations. You won't be disappointed. The menu reads like a poem. Waiting staff was lovely and hugely apologetic when they asked us to, well, get moving, after our 2 hours slot was through (actually, we were already 20min overdue). Beef stripes were heavenly, soft like well-cooked squid. Padron peppers are a staple, but do not fail to entice - that lovely mix of sweetness, spiciness, and saltiness; a green manifest of Umami. A leg of rabbit was tender, juicy, indecently so. We had red wine, and we had sweet wine for puds. Some had sherry before the affair had started. Choc puds made chatty girls tight-lipped and hoggish. Somehow I didn't mind. I was still licking my lips from the peppers.

eGycjztO_FPkGYHktVXnWQ.text: It's a bit hard to notice with scaffolding across the front, but it was a lovely find.  The wine list is fairly broad, ranging from the low-20's and up for a 750 ml bottle.  The asparagus with caramelized goat cheese was lovely--a nice mix of textures and flavors.  The chorizo with rocket on toast was spicy and filling.  The croquettes were very fluffy with a crisp coating.  Service was excellent and very friendly.  Definitely worth a visit.

zqDG3YNQNHK697-d26E5Aw.text: Having walked past this place a million and one times I had hopes of Tierra Brindisa. I'd read enough reviews by others to know that the back half with the bar was the best place to eat. And my forerunners were right; the airy second half of the room was a pleasurable light environment.We'd had no plans to dine out and as such hadn't thought of reservations, luckily it was relatively early and we were found a table for 3.The waitress who greeted us at the door was charming and accommodating, this trend continued throughout our meal. They smiled at our poor jokes, frequently cleared the tables and re-filled our glasses.To the dismay/confusion of my fellow diners I had already decided that choosing a wine would be easy. My theory that a good mid range European restaurant should have a quaffable fruity red under £20, perfect with tapas was met with a great house red (Tempranillo) at £16.50 (?).We opted for the staples of toast with tomato (what I've always known as Pan Tomaquet), and Potatoes with Aioli (not dissimilar to Patatas Bravas) for some starch to absorb the worryingly drinkable wine. They were both tasty well executed versions of their Spanish counterparts. We mulled over the cheeseboard, and having seen a few passed decided that it was quite possibly too much cheese for this occasion. Though having missed out, will mean that I'll inevitably have to go back.We opted for the deep fried goats cheese with honey and beetroot to ensure dairy received a mention. It was a beautiful combination of sweet/tart and creamy/crisp, and should rightfully spawn many a dinner party interpretation. We attempted to order the scallops from the specials, but were dutifully unformed that they had run out(read: some greedy person in front of us had eaten them all).All up we'd spent about £30's each had 2/3rd's of a bottle of wine and more food than you need in a day. Lovely service and great atmosphere, all in all a winning combination...9/10

J5CVUfbchNLDHwNkfKkY-Q.text: Friday night kicked off with a couple of pints of Landlord in the Feathers pub opposite St James tube as I waited with my old pals Kailesh and Mr Murphy for B to join us, and then it was off to Broadwick Street in Soho for a bit of food and a catch up at Tierra Brindisa. This branch of the growing Brindisa empire got our vote as it's nice and central but, more crucially when you are an eight strong party, you can book in advance. It has quite a different vibe from the London Bridge branch but that's no bad thing and in many ways it's a better choice if you want to spend the whole evening just drinking and chatting. We had bumped into another pal at the Feathers, the Hodge, and he was keen to join us so B gave them a call to see if they could accommodate another lover of fine tapas. Their advice that we could try to squeeze him onto our table at our own risk proved to be well founded when we arrived and surveyed the scene. However, we will no doubt be back with the Hodge in tow on another occasion. The restaurant has two two rooms, the larger of which is at the front with a smaller space out back with stools clustered around the bar for couples or solitary diners. The decor is all very neutral and simple, the lighting is well thought out and the furnishings are tasteful without being obtrusive. The focus here is on the food, providing a great setting for romance and/or conversation. Knowing our other guests only too well we ordered up some of the fragrant, floral "house" white along with some of the wonderful orange stuffed olives and alioli with quince paste, to supplement the "gratis" variety of nuts provided on our arrival, to stave off the hunger pangs and keep us in a cheery mood. As predicted some time around 8pm Maria and Priya arrived, with J and Julie Johnson rocking up shortly after, only a paltry 30 minutes late (some kind of record there J as my money was on 9pm!!) and we were good to go. The wine had been flowing pretty constantly since the moment we arrived so my recollection begins to get a bit hazy but we followed our normal plan of action at Brindisa and it's one that has served us well on many visits. We had an initial run at the menu ordering probably a dish each with a few orders of the tomato bread on top to start with; mainly focusing on the seafood and tortilla offerings. A second pass at the menu got a bit more messy but involved plenty of meat, yet more seafood and some vegetables and salad. J was in control of the wine by this stage and I vaguely recollect a fine bottle of Rioja. Stand-out dishes were plentiful but a special mention must be made of the divine little scallops with tiny rashers of bacon and minute new potatoes, the sardines which put me in mind of many wonderful meals in my spiritual home of Tavira, the pork fillet with sage, morcilla and roasted apple, the perfectly cooked lamb and a truely tasty version of the classic mushrooms on toast. In fact every dish was pretty much perfect other than the mussels which were a bit on the large side with a rubbery texture, just not the fresh and juicy specimens we have come to expect at Brindisa. However, that one complaint aside this was yet again another fine dining experience and it's a restaurant I would not hesitate to recommend. A crisp palate cleansing mango sorbet topped off with a candle was a lovely touch from the ever thoughtful Priya. A divine PX Valdespino sherry bursting with the flavour of raisins, with a whiff of sunnier climates, was followed by a quick espresso as we said a fond adieu to the guys and rushed yet again for the last train home in order to be up at the crack of dawn to travel North. As I checked my watch I realised that the lovely restaurant staff had obviously long since given up on their attempts to get us to vacate our table at 10pm and I wondered what lay ahead for the rest of the crew........ A very memorable evening and based on this experience a great venue for a fairly large party who want to eat top notch tapas, drink and make merry.

PoT2UeldRLbxl5KSQTbcGA.text: Tierra Brindisa is the spot for decent-to-pretty-good tapas in Soho. The menu is reasonable and the wine selection is fine (but lacking in by-the-glass options), but the experience was lacking in a way that I just couldn't put my finger on. A group of our colleagues meandered down to Broadwick Street for a nice tapas lunch not too long ago and ended up in the light, airy, but somehow still squished-feeling rear of the dining room. The server was nice, friendly, and helpful, but that's pretty much all I can remember about the service-element of the meal, for better or worse. The menu was similar to the service element in that I had to refer back to the website just now to even remember anything about it. Ah, yes, now I remember--pleasant, but unremarkable. There really was very little on the menu that piqued my interest the way that, say, the Stuffed And Honey Drizzled Courgette Flowers at Salt Yard can. All the tapas standards were there, except the patatas fritas that day, sadly. The fryer was broken and there was no way to improvise. I do remember the dipping oil for the bread being quite fantastic, but I'm not sure what it says about a menu that the only thing I specifically remember was the dipping oil.All in all, the meal was perfectly nice and not at all unpleasant. I think that Tierra Brindisa has perhaps been harmed by the prevalence of really extraordinary tapas restaurants in Soho such as Salt Yard and Dehesa because as lovely as it was, it doesn't hold a candle to either of its rivals. This is a high-3-nearly-4 star review I'm giving, but a few exciting additions to its menu would help move it up a bracket to a solid 4.

N4oUkwKTpdhuOc9tC6CGVw.text: One of the better tapas places in London IMO.  Quality of the food was good and so was the atmosphere but it was a little on the pricey side

vIpeKZQB_Nn_bhMAs_I5Sw.text: You can't go wrong with tapas can you really? If you don't like one thing, you can move on to the next, and it's almost rude not to get drunk. I really enjoy the pick and mix approach to food that tapas provides, and when the selection is as good as it as at Brindisa then I'm like a kid in sweet shop. Terrific tortilla, champion chorizo, even the octopus (not the psychic one!) went down a treat. And I drank more sherry than my great aunty has drunk in her lifetime. And you don't need a second mortgage to cover the bill. Spot on.

TyBo-u728ug0qSP-G31Y3Q.text: Probably the best tapas in London. It's in a quieter corner of Soho and the place is buzzing inside. The menu isn't overwhelming with choices but that's the way it should be. The quality of the ingredients and produce is absolutely fantastic. I particularly loved the cheeses: Roncal with quince paste is a favorite.

TRltLoJ1m5evPVugsgITGg.text: It's actually pretty ironic that I made the effort to come here since, as a vegetarian, I'm not really a huge fan of the Spanish's jamon-based cuisine, and I don't even like Brindisa's sister stall at Borough Market at all (I tend to avoid any shop with garish pig legs on display) - but I didn't exactly put all those things together when I told my date to make a reservation (and definitely make one!  Otherwise, you could be in for a two hour wait...)Rather, I was merely intrigued by this small and charming sage-coloured restaurant since it always looked so bustling and romantically lit inside - plus, I'd happened to notice that olives and cheese (practically my dietary staples) figured prominently on the menu.  I made one foolish attempt to go here randomly with a friend ("sure," the hostess said, "we can get you a seat in a couple of hours" ha!) before I had a date ask if I had "any thoughts on a restaurant" (normally I hate that question!) to which I immediately responded, "Tierra Brindisa" - still rather oblivious to the fact that it had anything to do with that stall in Borough, or that it was London's newest Spanish tapas restaurant - I was *that* anxious to try it based on exterior looks alone.  The inside is really small and intimate... with tiny tables appropriate for the little white plates of nibbles that follow.  We started out with glasses of some rather enjoyable sherry and the Gordal olives (of course), which were splendid... substantial with a fantastic smack of orange - so good, in fact, that I'll probably come back just to have them again.  Then came the spinach, which, as a huge spinach fan, it would had to have been pretty sub-par for me not to enjoy it, but this was really interesting and different - studded with pine nuts and some plump and succulent raisins.  My date liked the bread with tomato (a traditional Spanish dish that I've never quite understood) and his lamb.  However, neither one of us were particularly found of the lentil stew - the goats curd with it didn't quite work.  But oh! the fried goats cheese with honey was the superb smash of the night!  The absolutely perfect rich balance of sweet and salty.  Although the service was a little slow (but nice), I found this to be one of the more brilliant tapas restaurants I've been to.  If you're looking for something a bit different to impress a date with, this could be it.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom

ZIELHYyQ_yspAFvoj4xr_g.text: Had the octopus that was good and cheeses that were nice.. staff was great from front of house to the back of house (who walked me though the cheeses) would have loved to eat more but was 10pm when i walked in. Little late to indulge.

iwEHpvSKnInQN4cXfIh53g.text: Definitely try the oxtail croquette and the jamon Iberica Paloma.  But overall we weren't wowed by the staples: papas bravas, pan y coco, et cetera. Our seat neighbors recommended the giant prawn by we were too full by then. Will be heading to sister location next since that joint is even better reviewed than this one.

cf-kmj8ydusGJySbRq5Puw.text: Brandissa should just stick to the stand at Borough Market because the restaurant leaves a lot to be desired. The service was terrible; we had to askmultiple times for things like a spoon for soup or drink refills. Other than the tortilla each dish was pretty flavourless including the octopus, pan con tomate, short rib and a few other dishes that were completely forgettable. The bill of nearly £200 for4 of us (2 of the 4 who didn't drink) is a true sign of over priced rubbish. Don't waste your time when Barrafina is just around the corner!!!

GRcEnAF2E1_NMzLN4Sm7TA.text: Overview: The atmosphere is like most of the tapas bar, nothing much special. We sat by the bar, so can't say if it is more intimate or romantic if you sit inside. Food is served in a way I like: one after another, we never had two plates on our table, but didn't wait for long for the next dish. I love everything we ordered, and more details below. So it is good if you want something casual to have, and it is not too pricy.Gambas: the oil was still boiling when it was brought to the table. It is a very common dish in a tapas bar, but it tasted better than average. You can tell the prawn is fresh, and the hot oil kept its original flavour together with the flavour of the spices. Pulpo: again, very common dish, but better than average. Cordero: it is ok, nothing too special about it, but tasty.Carrillera: I love it so much! I think it is slow cooked, and it is so tender! You could feel it is melting in your mouth! The flavour of the spices was not strong and it went very well with the meat. It came with mash sweet potatoes, which is creamy and soft. Love it so much!Presa: this is amazing! I am not a pork lover myself, but it is cooked in a so much tender way, and I have to say I love it! It is not far at all, but when you bite it, it is so juicy and creamy. I am not a fan of green peppers, but the flavour of the green pepper mixed very well with the pork. Definitely recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom. Prawn
Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom. Octopus leg
Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom. Lamb

gWXU09kc7k-Ye9H7_9SbCg.text: Came with friends while in London whom have eaten here before so I was excited to try it since they really know their food and have great palates.Friday night and the plate was packed, wanted to sit indoors and was given an hour and 45 mins time allotment to finish dinner- that was fine with us because we were starving already.Our server was kind enough to split our bill beforehand and drinks were delivered at a reasonable timeframe. I ordered the patatas bavas, gambas al ajillo, octopus, Catalan spinach, and salt cod fritters. Everything was superb- portion size, presentation, and taste! Great for sharing and experiencing tapas at its best.The reason for not giving it 5 stars, after we finished the main course, dessert menus were given to us we didn't see our server for at least 20 minutes after. Flagging down another server to order desserts, our server finally shows up. She explains she had to take her break, on a packed Friday night at 8:30??? Not sure if this is a required routine or a whim because when we were finished with our main course, the hostess came to check on our table to see if we were finished yet. When we finally got to order our desserts, we chose an almond tart, and vanilla mousse with raspberry which were both delicious!The hostess came over again and had to run our check charges because our server was too busy- again feeling pushed out but was really was not our fault.Been in this business too long, if there is a time restraint for the table, the server should be informed and stay on top of it- don't make the customer feel like "eat it, and now beat it"Don't let my experience steer you away- the food, ambience, and decor will definitely keep you happy.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom. My friends chorizo- best I've tasted!
Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom. Salt cod tempura.
Photo of Tapas Brindisa Soho - London, United Kingdom. Octopus- amazing!

xtOdynf6Clul670fcZX2gQ.text: This place has the smallest queue in Soho and the quickest service! Protip: try to ask for a table in the back to watch the creators work their magic. If you're confused on how many dishes to order, try 2 per person and then one if your starving. Servers are honest about the portion size. Top recommended dishes: truffle honey cheese and the lambDEFINITELY pair dinner with their wine selection.

Mg-xDA4HTArVgxib1ttnSw.text: Nice little joint in central. We didn't have a reservation for an after work sitting but managed to get a table for two without a long wait. Quite busy, ambience was ok, little noisy. Good wine, food was lovely and service was great. I wouldn't order their coffee though.. That was definitely not so great.

JOsf_BSzf7qcp9H2S_ojiA.text: This was my first time at a Tapas Brindisa - and I really enjoyed it! The restaurant itself is quite cosy, but we were able to get a table as it Tuesday lunchtime (good time to go!)We (3 of us) ordered the ham croquettes, the cheese board, the bomba, a manchego salad, potatoes and the catalan spinach. We shared everything and it was definitely enough food for us!The croquetas de jamon were not what i was expecting, but they were delicious nonetheless! (I'm used to Cuban croquetas!) The cheese selection was very good, although it tended towards goats cheeses, so if you're not into that... oh well.The least enjoyable dish we had was the manchego salad- the dressing was a little oily and didn't have much flavour. everything else was great! they even brought us some more aoli sauce, which was super delicious.I would recommend this place and i can't wait to go back!

pXpSAGNT9F9gmFBBtibuLg.text: Great place if in the mood for tapas. Small space and gets crowded. They don't take reservations and don't recommend if you are more than 4 people due to space. Although they said they would pave our dishes out they all came out at once so order in waves. The service was good and efficient even though they are busy they accommodate their guests. Food was good but nothing wowed me but defiantly hit the spot.

-LIqXEEF5fqhQroaML4-Sw.text: I should probably caveat that tapas is not my food of choice but friends seem to enjoy it so I will tag along. The food was good at Brindisa and I understand its popularity. The quality is high but nothing really stood out as amazing. The charcuterie plate was copious but the slices of meat were very thinly sliced.  Too much so, in my opinion.  I don't think they could have made them any thinner!Tortilla did what it said in the tin. I liked that is was a thickly cut wedge rather than some of the thinner pieces you sometimes get. Spinach salad with pine nuts and raisins was tasty but not necessarily anything to write home about. Prawns cooked with garlic could have had a bit more garlicky-ness to them but they were well cooked and not overdone. I enjoyed this the most. Ham croquettes weren't that interesting. Mushy potato with ham, deep fried with a crunchy coating.  I should stop ordering these. They sound better than they ever are!It was a fine way to pass a leisurely lunchtime visit but I wouldn't make it a destination spot by my means. That said, if you are a big tapas fan, I think you will enjoy Brindisa.

oBviFKOS1WDgKeYDNqmbDA.text: Excellent tapas.  Great selection.  Everything was tasty, well executed, and reasonably priced.  Great selection of Spanish wine and cava.  3 Spanish beers on tap.  Nice decor.  Friendly staff.  What more could you want?

0YEKNK0GtNBkJe2B2SzGPQ.text: Food was OK taste wise, but the portions were quite stingy and overpriced for the quality. Sangria was mediocre.

7GdxN5EpFtpmyfewNjSeeg.text: Great little tapas spot in Soho.  I went on a Friday for lunch and got a table outside (there are only 2 outside!) Service was excellent - our waitress recommended an amazing bottle of wine and had the perfect recommendations for what to order and how much. Everything was great.  A bit pricey, but typical for the area.

huXTafKN1RNlmSJIIlPIkQ.text: Firstly, this place does not take reservations on a Friday night so we had to wait for our table. What else could we do but prop up the bar (once the space was available) and sample some wine. It didn't take as long as we thought for a table to become free and once we were seated, we set about ordering everything that sounded even mildly tempting. All of us are big charcuterie and cheese fans and the Iberico board was very generous and packed full of delicious meats. The cheese board was smaller but each cheese came with a suitable pairing like membrillo or fig. The croquettas are creamy and delicious and are worth a special mention! There were a couple more plates but the thing that was really special was the salt cod. This came up served with apple. Yes, fish and fruit. i thought the same, that cannot work but it does!! and it is delicious! A sentiment shared by all three of us initially skeptical women. I rounded off the evening with a crema catalana  (shared between three!) and a sherry that touted itself as 'christmas pudding in a glass' and like the rest of the food, this completely delivered.

Dic2tzhFsAo6VpmitB4igg.text: Spanish tapas spot with a small open kitchenFood: 4, Service: 4, Atmosphere: 3Cost to worth it rating: 3.5Return worthiness: maybeHighlights:- Cooked pork: really tender and delicious with cocoa and apple accompaniments. My friend was worried about the default rare on pork so negotiated to medium rare and it was divine.- Eggplant: sliced and cold and then put together and shaped. Nice flavors and I appreciated the salty tapenade on top. The grilled chewy olive oil dusted bread slices were the perfect pairing.- Jamon sampler: can't go wrong with Spanish ham :-)Midlights:- Shrimp: typically one of my favorites but these lacked any flavor even with the garlic pieces in the hot olive oil. Shrimp was a nice large size and springy cooked just right texture.Lowlights:- Sangria: in a champagne glass so bit hard to drink and recover the fruits. Not much flavor and oddly served with a straw.Some hits and misses, but would consider coming back for the pork and to try a few other dishes.

Dr-wTNWtsehHfMb_8ZRhHA.text: I really liked it. I've been to the Borough Market branch and for some reason I found it less enjoyable that the Soho one. I went there with 2 more friends and we did have a good time.The ox cheeks were so so soft that it melts in your mouth. Pork belly nice and crispy. And the rest of the tapas were very very decent. I liked the small cozy atmosphere -- though I would turn the lights a bit down.As for the service - quick and efficient. On the arrival we were handed two half pints which were poured by mistake - a cool start for a good outing. We did have to wait about 40 minutes for a table while enjoying the free beer and sangria. And maybe I'm just not a fan of sangria - but it was too watery and too much fruit (I ended up with a cup full of just fruit and ice and no space for the actual drink).I will come back - just for the ox cheeks alone.

9GbN_bEgQblt4Bpq6H6SQA.text: It's small (it's Soho), but it's got decent tapas fare. I've eaten here twice. Once was just the other night, and I feel like the decor or seating arrangement had changed since the previous time, but I can't be certain. Everything came on time and tasted as I expected it. The service was OK, though the waitress was a bit awkward. She kept staring at me after I ordered, as though I hadn't spoken yet. Weirdo.Fair wine selection. Noisy crowd, both times I've been. And, the first time, I was with a girl who decided to cry during the meal. Not due to the food or service. It must have been something I did. That was fun. The servers were nice enough to leave us alone during most of it, so that was alright.Lastly, the front door doesn't close on it's own. Be a good lad and close it behind you, or your fellow diners (especially the ones in the front) might get chilly.

mvgWca1bOp7xPs6OlSy4NA.text: Wrote a review for this place a few years back and had a bit of a moan about it. Came here a couple of weeks ago and had a much better time.The quality of the food was still excellent, but the size of the dishes had improved greatly from my last visit. My friend and I got in here quite late, but the manager was very accommodating. The place has had a refurb since I was last in, and seems a lot better for it. We sat by the window at the front, and the manger talked me through a couple of dishes I was unaware of, and i'm glad he did as it was really good.Overall it was just over £50 for a few dishes and a bottle of wine, good value for the quality of the food.

RxxUTe_yLrb_eqTI1ZUfSw.text: I absolutely love Tapas, I like to drink wine and pick, this restaurant is deceptively bigger than it looks but still intimate and cosy. It has a lovely atmosphere and the staff are friendly and helpful, the food is great even if a tad on the expensive side but to be expected in London!!! Really enjoyed our evening out here!!

sM0UugiRT1KNbvl0jQ-NuQ.text: Went to this place on my last night in London and my experience helped make it one of the best nights of my month-long stay in England. We got a bottle of wine to split between four of us and enjoyed the outdoor seating with a view of the Market. We split aioli with bread that I only wish I could recreate. I got the wilted spinach with pine nuts and chorizo with rocket and roasted red peppers on grilled bread. I have tried to recreate both because they were so insanely delicious. There are certain spots that I've encountered in my travels that make me want to go back to the city just to experience again. I can't wait for the next time I travel to London so that I can order that meal one more time. I won't even go near any tapas places in New York because I'm afraid it'll taint my experience at Brindasa.Great to walk around Borough Market first and then stop off for dinner before a show at the Globe or some sight-seeing. Also great date spot. I went in early August during the last week of the 2012 Olympics and even then it was peaceful, relaxing, and not at all over-crowded.
